required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ideal Anatomic Location for Saphenous Nerve Blocks: A Prospective Clinical Evaluation
clinical_study.official_title: Ideal Anatomic Location for Saphenous Nerve Blocks: A Prospective Clinical Evaluation

brief_summary.textblock: This research is being done to compare two different saphenous nerve block locations and will help to determine which site best maintains knee strength and pain control.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective, randomized, observer blinded clinical trial comparing motor strength in knee extension between two sets of patients, one receiving a proximal thigh block of the saphenous nerve and one receiving a distal thigh block of the saphenous nerve. The secondary objectives are to compare the pain relief and quality of life of participants in these two groups.

primary_outcome.measure: knee extensor strength measured in kilograms
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline preoperatively to 30 minutes after nerve block placement
primary_outcome.description: Strength of the knee extensors in both treatment arms (distal vs. proximal block) will be tested preoperatively and again 30 minutes after the nerve block by using a hand-held dynamometer measured in kilograms

secondary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline preoperatively to two weeks post-operatively
secondary_outcome.description: Pain relief will be measured by review of the medical record for type and amount of pain medications used

secondary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline preoperatively to two weeks post-operatively
secondary_outcome.description: PROMIS Global Health Survey will be completed by patients in both treatment arms pre-operatively and again two weeks post-operatively

arm_group.description: The anesthesiologist will administer a saphenous proximal nerve block if specified in the randomization envelope.
The anesthesiologist will administer a saphenous distal nerve block if specified in the randomization envelope.

intervention.description: A nerve block will be performed by the anesthesiologist. The location of the nerve block will be per randomization envelope (proximal vs. distal) and performed just prior to foot or ankle surgical procedures that require a saphenous nerve block

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18-65
- Upcoming elective foot or ankle surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Preoperative weakness in knee extension
- Documented neuropathy
- Previous knee surgery
- Inability to provide informed consent

facility.name: Penn State Milton S. Hershey Medical Center

clinical_study.keyword: nerve blocks in foot and ankle surgery
